Package com.lopl.melody.settings

Class Setting<T extends SettingValue>

java.lang.Object
com.lopl.melody.settings.Setting<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the link to the SettingValue class
Direct Known Subclasses:
AutomaticRecording, DefaultMusicType, MusicPlayerProvider
public abstract class Setting<T extends SettingValue>
extends java.lang.Object
This is the abstract class for a Setting. Extend this to implement a setting. Each setting needs a "Value" class that extends the SettingValue class. This class is the Data holder of the setting and stores the state

Example: 

 public class MySetting extends Setting{
   [all the methods]
   public static class MySettingValue extends SettingValue{
     [all the methods]
   }
 }

  • Field Details

    • value

      private T extends SettingValue value
      Value variable

    • name

      protected java.lang.String name
      This is the name of the setting. Set this in the constructor.

  • Constructor Details

    • Setting

      protected Setting()
      Constructor for the base Setting. This will set the current value to the default value declared in getDefaultValue(). The super constructor (this) must be called in every Subclass

  • Method Details

    • getDefaultValue

      @Nonnull protected abstract T getDefaultValue()
      This should return the initial SettingValue. It will be set as the current value for the setting in the constructor.
      Returns:
      a Nonnull value of SettingValue

    • getPossibilities

      public abstract java.util.List<T> getPossibilities()
      This should return all possible values for the setting. You can make this a single liner with List.of()

      Example: 

       return List.of(myPossibleValue, myOtherValue);
      Returns:
      a list (Nonnull and not Empty) containing all values of SettingValue

    • updateData

      public abstract void updateData​(int data)
      This is called whenever a new data wants to be applied. You should implement the Value change and check for impossible states.

      Example: 

       setValue(new MySettingValue(data));
 if (data <= 0 || data >= 4)
   setValue(getDefaultValue());
      Other code can be added as you like
      Parameters:
      data - a int containing the value representation

    • getValueRepresentation

      public java.lang.String getValueRepresentation()
      Change this to change the appearance of the Value String. You should consider overriding the SettingValue.getValueRepresentation() first.
      Returns:
      a String describing the current value;

    • getValue

      public T getValue()
      Returns:
      Getter for value

    • setValue

      public void setValue​(T v)
      Parameters:
      v - Setter for value

    • getDatabaseName

      public java.lang.String getDatabaseName()
      This algorithm converts the simple class name from Upper-Camelcase to Lower-Underscore-Case. The returned String is used to store the setting in a database.

      Example: 

       MyClassSetting -> my_class_setting
      Please do not Override this
      Returns:
      Class name in lower_underscore_case

    • getName

      public java.lang.String getName()
      Returns the displayed Setting name. Can be set in the constructor with name. Or you can override this method.
      Returns:
      Display name of the Setting
